title: Can two elements have the same electron configuration? - Quora

response.answer_text: Not unless one of them is ionized. Every element has a unique atomic number and therefore a unique number of electrons in its unionized elemental form. You can’t have the same electron configuration with different numbers of electrons. However, if you allow ionization, then it is possible. For example, oxide ion, fluoride ion, neon, sodium ion, magnesium ion and aluminum ion all have the same ground-state electron configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p⁶.

Isotopes have same electronic configuration. Isotope are those elements which have same atomic number but different mass number. Since isotope have same number of electrons, so they have same electronic configuration. All isoelectronic species have same electronic configuration.
